New-York Historical Society
Time Inc. The March of Time Records
Time, inc.
MS 3009-RG 15
21 Linear feet in 21 record cartons which includes 10 reels of microfilm
1935-1995 The Time Inc. The March of Time Records contain materials used in the production of the radio, film, and television versions of the show as well as in the production of films that The March of Time created for outside organizations. The majority of the materials are related to the film version of the show that was broadcast in theaters from 1935 to 1951.
Historical Note
The March of Time originally debuted on March 6, 1931 as radio newsreel on CBS Radio. The show was developed by Fred Smith, a radio executive, and Roy Larsen while he was the circulation director of Time. The two envisioned the show as a way to dramatize the news and reenact events that could not be reported live. At first, the show focused on domestic stories, but changed its focus at the beginning of World War II and began reporting on international events as well. In 1942, the show switched to providing straightforward news reports which relied on Time correspondents around the world instead of dramatized reenactments. The radio news program continued until 1945.
During The March of Time radio broadcast, Louis De Rochemont, a director of short films for Fox Movietone News, heard the show and had the idea for something he termed "pictoral journalism" which would recreate The March of Time on film. De Rochemont brought his idea to Larsen, and they began work on the film version of The March of Time in June 1934. The first episode of the film version debuted at the Capitol Theatre in New York City on February 1, 1935. While there had been newsreels shown before and between films before this point, their popularity had declined after the advent sound films. The March of Time would update and modernize the newsreels that had previously been seen. Unlike older versions of newsreels that avoided reporting on current events or anything controversial, The March of Time aimed to report events as they happened and included stories found on the pages of Time and Life. The show also included archival footage from the federal governemt, reenactments, interviews, and dramatic voice-overs. As the show matured and expanded, there were fewer reenactments and more interviews. With the rise of television and the costs of production, Time Inc. attempted to reduce the number films of The March of Time in the hope to reduce the costs while allowing the show to still exist. While this strategy did reduce costs, it also reduced profits. Due to budgetery issues, The March of Time newsreels ended in August 1951.
An attempt to relaunch the show was started in 1964. This relaunch would broadcast the show on the television channel WNEW instead of in theaters and was created together with the Metropolitan Broadcasting Company. While the original series provided news about current events, the relaunch appeared to have been about historical events and reused ideas and storylines from the original series. This version of the show did not last long and seems to have ended in 1966.
While in theaters, The March of Time delivered new newsreels on a monthly basis to thousands of theaters across the United States and abroad. At its peak, newsreels provided by The March of Time were played in 13,000 theaters and received forty awards and prizes including two Oscars from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Despite the awards and accolades, The March of Time was only profitable during two years of production, 1938 and 1939. Nevertheless, Time Inc. viewed The March of Time as a worthwhile vehicle to solidify its reputation as a news provider.

Doll, Susan. "Introduction to THE MARCH OF TIME." Turner Classic Movies. Accessed October 24, 2018. http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/343404|0/75th-Anniversary-of-The-March-of-Time.html.
Elson, Robert T., and Duncan Norton-Taylor. 1973. The World of Time Inc.: The Intimate History of a Publishing Enterprise, 1941-1960. New York: Atheneum.
National Radio Hall of Fame. "The March of Time." National Radio Hall of Fame. Accessed October 24, 2018. http://nationalradiohalloffame.com/march_of_time.htm.
Prendergast, Curtis, and Geoffrey Colvin. 1986. The World of Time Inc.: The Intimate History of a Changing Enterprise, 1960-1980. New York: Atheneum.
Scope and Contents
The The March of Time Records contain scripts used in the production of The March of Time for film and radio; production files for films created for other organization by The March of Time; and videocassettes of The March of Time films, episodes, and clips.
Arrangement
The record group is arranged into three series:
Series I. Scripts
Series II. Commercial Productions
Series III. Audiovisual
Custodial History
Gift of Time Inc. in 2015.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to qualified researchers with the exception of restricted materials. Restricted materials may include contracts and consent forms. Restricted boxes include R40 and R41. Unreformatted audiovisual and digital material in the collection is not accessible. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. Although the N-YHS owns this collection as physical property, the donor specifically retains all copyright and all other proprietary rights which may exist. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as Time Inc. The March of Time Records, MS 3009-RG 15, New-York Historical Society.
Related Materials
This finding aid relates to just one record group of the Time Inc. Records. For information about the other record groups and for overall information about the archives, please see the Guide to the Time Inc. Records (MS 3009). The Henry Luce Papers (MS 3014) were acquired with the Time Inc. Records. The collection of books acquired with the records are cataloged as the Time Inc. Reference Library.
Additional records from The March of Time and regarding its history can be found in the Time Inc. Subject Files (MS 3009-RG1).
Processing Information
The Time Inc. The March of Time Files were processed by Samantha Brown in 2018. The original folders were retained although some documents were transferred to archival containers in instances of overcrowding or if no original folder was present. Brown created the inventory and other descriptive notes for the record group. Series were created based on the original groups of materials. Within series, materials were arranged in their original order. If no order was present then an order was imposed.

Series I. Scripts6 Linear feetin 7 record cartons including 10 reels of microfilm1935-1974
Scope and Contents
The Scripts series contains scripts used in the production of The March of Time for film and radio. Additionally, there are indexes and continuities that provide lists of episodes created, episode titles if they exist, and sometimes summaries of the episodes' contents. The terms index and continuity seem to be used interchangeably and refer to the same type of document.
Arrangement
Arranged into two subseries:
Subseries I.A. Films
Subseries I.B. Radio.Subseries I.A. Films5.75 Linear feetin 7 record cartons including 2 reels of microfilm1935-1953, 1974, undated
Scope and Contents
The Films subseries contains the scripts used in the production of the March of Time film series that played in theaters from 1935 through 1951. In addition to the scripts, the sub-series also contains indexes and continuities. The continuities are on microfilm. All other materials in this series are on paper.

Scope and Contents
The Radio subseries contains microfilm versions of the scripts used in the production of the radio version of March of Time which broadcast from 1931 through 1945. An index to the episodes is included on the first reel of microfilm. Materials are dated based on contents and not date of microfilm imaging.

Scope and Contents
The Commercial Productions series contains materials related to the production of films that The March of Time created for organizations outside of Time Inc. The creator of the files labeled them "Commercial," but they are not for advertising commercials. These films were usually used to build support for an organization or build morale within a professional organization. The materials contained in this series includes scripts, consent forms, both internal and external correspondence related to the creation and production of the films, lists of actors, lists of set details and supplies, lists of key numbers, cameraman dope sheets, newspaper and magazine clippings, handwritten notes related to changes in film production, purchase orders, bills of service, and lists of music. Only files for A to C are present.

Scope and Contents
The Audiovisual series contains videocassettes related to The March of Time. The majority of tapes include episodes of The March of Time but some tapes, such as Time Warner: The Changing Face of Media and Entertainment and the WPA Film Library Sample Reel, only contain clips from the show. Those tapes which include episodes of The March of Time are undated but includes episodes of the show from 1935 to 1951. While the majority of tapes contain tapes from one volume, some tapes include episodes from multiple volumes.
Unreformatted audiovisual and digital material in the collection is not accessible.
Arrangement
Arranged into two subseries:
Subseries IV.A. Internal Use
Subseries IV.B. Commercially DistributedSubseries III.A. Internal Use11 Linear feetin 11 record cartons1979-1995, undated
Scope and Contents
The Internal Use subseries contains videocassettes that were created for use within Time Inc. or for preservation purposes. These tapes mainly contain episodes of March of Time but Time Warner: The Changing Face of Media and Entertainment is assumed to contain only clips from The March of Time. While the majority of tapes contain episodes from one volume, some tapes include episodes from multiple volumes.
Arrangement
Arranged in their original order by volume number and with special releases at the end. If a tape includes episodes from multiple volumes then that tape is placed with the earliest volume on the tape.Untitledundated27991

Scope and Contents
The Commercially Distributed subseries contains videocassettes that were produced for the general public to purchase.
Arrangement
Arranged alphabetically.March of Time: America at War: Special Collector's Edition Box Set198728101
Scope and Contents
One box set with six videocassettes. Included in the set:
1 videocassette (VHS) (116 min.): 1/2 in. Title: "The March of Time presents America at War Friend and Foe Part 1"
1 videocassette (VHS) (87 min.): 1/2 in. Title: "The March of Time Presents America at War Friend and Foe Part 2"
1 videocassette (VHS) (113 min): 1/2 in. Title: "The March of Time Presents America at War Friend and Foe Part 3". Includes a note: "Vol. XI issue #4 Inside China Today December 1944"
